job_title: Admin Officer 2 in La Jolla, CA
pros: Working for UCSD in general is good. If you stay for the long haul, then the pension is good. Some supervisors are interested in your growth if you let them know. Most departments are overall pleasant enough to work with. Some depts may offer an opportunity to work from home a couple days a week, but depends on your role and the dept needs.
cons: Most times hard to move up within same dept. You sometimes need to dept hop to further your career or to make more money. A couple of times I really liked the dept and people I worked with, but there would not be an opportunity to move up in my role, and I would have to make the choice to apply for a higher position in another dept. Parking is not free on LJ campus or in Hillcrest. Parking can sometimes be a good walk from your car to your building. I wish more depts would offer 1-3 days work from home opportunities for better work/life balance. As well, this can help with your parking and gas costs, and travel time.

job_title: Graduate Program Coordinator in La Jolla, CA
pros: *Loved working with students. *Nice campus, great views especially on the west side of campus. *Lovely coworkers. *Purpose driven work.
cons: *Low pay for staff that it should be criminal. NO cost of living increases, and raises capped at 3% per year and in 2020 we didn't get any raises. *Understaffed. Some departments haven't increased staffing in 10+ years when student population has increased dramatically. *Administration is out of touch and at least one vice chancellor has been caught responding to staff complaints about a new HR/financial system to "hire better staff." Same person also told graduate students facing unprecedented rent hikes to "take this as an opportunity to budget better." This person makes $300k+ per year. Absolutely unacceptable. *Parking ridiculously expensive and even if you work here, you have to pay. *Some buildings are old and have no air conditioning, and have been rated as in danger of serious damage in case of earthquakes. *Ton of bureaucracy.

job_title: Event Specialist in San Diego, CA
pros: UC San Diego is great place among staff for one collective reason: We love to serve students and support the students. In between we can create, collaborate and problem solve to support the goals of the department and our main stakeholders. Due to the nature of the work, there is a good attitude and atmosphere among staff, and depending on the supervisor it can contribute to a flexible and fair work enviroment.
cons: It is a large institution with the problems that large institutions can gloss over. Much of the decision making for staff can fall on the individual supervisors that can make or break an employee's experience here. Since UCSD is an older institution I find that many of the experienced supervisors have a difficult time going against their status quo in employee suggestions and demands such as WFH, flex time, and use of time off. Policies are written to fit the needs of the supervisor and department, which leads a lot of the decision making to them.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: I taught in a writing program. I had two classes of ~25 students a quarter. I was responsible for reading the course materials, and leading discussions of these materials and the subjects covered in lecture. My supervisors were very supportive, always trying to accommodate my needs and keeping me in mind when additional opportunities arose.
cons: While the workload was manageable, that manageability often came at the cost of doing minimal work. For example, reading and grading 50 (8 page long) students papers was doable provided that I developed a clear rubric for evaluation and used fairly standard comments; at the same time, this method meant that I did not give much individualized feedback--had I tried, the job would have become too much to manage time-wise. This could make is frustrating.

job_title: Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Co-workers are nice. Benefits are ok, no tuition reimbursement.
cons:
Upper leadership is totally disconnected from their employees. Almost all departments are severely understaffed, however leadership continues to increase workloads. 

The work volume is unmanageable, and the project list is never ending. To add to this frustration, many project are abandoned simply because leadership changes their mind. 

There are no annual increases. There is a merit incentive only offered to high performers, which is 1-3% per year, a complete joke. No way to reward employees or incentivize them with standard annual increases, comparable to other companies (5-15%).

Current employees need to find and apply to other positions in order to get any kind of normal pay increase.

review_title: Decent Pay, Decent Location for Classes
job_title: Student Manager in La Jolla, CA
pros:
On the plus side, the pay is alright for the work you do, and it's fairly easy to get promoted to higher levels (student lead, student manager) if you show up regularly, and are a solid worker. In addition, these promotions are usually group affairs, so you'll have a cohort of folks to help you out while you advance. Generally coworkers are very good here, in particular some of the career coworkers are some of the nicest folks I've met, period. 

Beyond this, two other benefits stand out in comparison to other jobs I've had - for one they will *always* schedule around your classes, school events, and clubs as long as you notify them of your schedule. On top of that, your schedule can be negotiated, and is reasonably flexible. And to put an extra layer of icing on the cake, if you live on-campus, you'll be assigned the unit closest to you (as long as they need staff). 

The second major boon is the Perq program - for student workers and leads, you get $10 in Perq per shift (with more if you work >6hrs, or more than one shift a day) and for student managers it jumps up to $19. This may not sound like a lot, but it can be as much as two to three proper meals during your shifts, all for what is essentially free. I've met students who keep working here simply because the Perq program exists and gets them half of their meals for the week - hell I've been that student for months at a time.
cons:
One of the first major cons is the volatility of your student coworkers. For a lot of folks, this is their first job, and as such if you're a student manager, you'll be expected to train them through all the basics they need to work in HDH. Don't get me wrong, I've met some good friends through HDH, and you will too! But you'll also meet folks who just make you want to pull your hair out, and there's really not much you can do about it besides being kind and pushing on. 

Beyond all of this, I really do need to mention the pay issue. With Covid-19, I understand that HDH had a genuinely rough year, however the fact that pay here remains scarcely above minimum wage (when I started it *was* minimum wage) is a little frustrating. I get that this is a pocket-change job for some of the students here, but for a lot of us (myself included) it's how we pay our bills; or at least part of that equation. Frankly I can only think of two coworkers who were satisfied with their hourly pay, and it's often the case that we'd discuss how boned the campus would be if all the students here quit on account of low pay, and how frustrating it is that HDH doesn't acknowledge that and pay us a decent wage for our work. Dining is definitely not where they're making most of their money, but it's a cornerstone of campus, and the folks holding that up - regardless of if they're students, career chefs, or managers - should be compensated appropriately.

job_title: Lab Assistant I in La Jolla, CA
pros: Working at UCSD offered great benefits (health, dental, vision), and even priority access to COVID testing and vaccines. The working environment was nice and since it involves lab research, work hours can be flexible at times.
cons: Pay for lab assistants was low, commute (when COVID wasn't a thing) was awful due to traffic (1.5 hours one-way when you drive up from El Cajon), Parking was hard to find (Pre-COVID) so you'd have to park 30 mins away from work. Allocation of work duties felt off sometimes since I kept getting referred to as a job position much higher than I had, and given responsibilities as such even though I was getting entry-level pay. No overtime pay given, even when lab duties force you to work extra or on the weekends.

review_title: Good Benefits, But outsourcing and department mergers for efficiency leads to overwork
job_title: Network Administrator in San Diego, CA
pros:
Great Benefits
Work life balance can be great if you find a niche that keeps you stable (don't take on any new work or projects)
Friendly staff
Company culture is what you make of it. Staff is mostly Boomers and responds to them (they run the place), but is slowly getting younger.
Good manager (mine was great, results vary)

If you stick around long enough, you get to the golden years of great retirement benefits and maybe get to a management position if you go to school (plan on it).

Slow pace of projects because its education. Projects take a long time. Pro or con depending on how you see it.
cons:
The university IT staff has gone from Research focused to Business focused. They Brough in C-Suite executives that only care about efficiency and costs.

They outsourced a lot of in house staff to Cloud, and Software as a service, *buzzword as a service, companies. What this boils down to is jobs lost on site and knowledge lost on site. Sure, the complexity and cost is reduced from month to month on site, but that has just been pushed elsewhere (to the cloud!)

Now you have to call clueless tech support to get anything done instead of walking over to your in house staff to get things done. Let's be real here, C-Suite staff just want lower costs and reduce staff.

You ultimately get more work put on you if you're good at your job.

I stuck around for 10 years seeing reduced staffing. I got maybe 17% pay bump in that time, but it was not worth it, except for the pay out in benefits. I could have jumped to Google, or any FAANG company in the early days for $$$.

job_title: Faculty in La Jolla, CA
pros: Nice campus, great colleagues, great students.  Very nice place to work.  Graduate and undergraduate students are smart and motivated and a pleasure to work with.
cons: Staffing is a complete nightmare.  The bureaucracy is terrible.  There is no training into how to hire people and the rules constantly change resulting in frustration and wasted effort.  HR negotiates with the union and only appears to protect employees.  Although there are many outstanding staff members, the system can select for the  incompetent, especially as the job market is hot in San Diego and university pay is lower than in industry.  If your group is small, making the wrong hire can be a devastating error as  the union makes it very hard to let people go.  Young untenured faculty who have small groups and less experience are likely to be hurt the most by making a hire who is a bad fit.  Because one is afraid to hire, you tend to hire less and make do with a smaller staff, which results in more stress for existing employees and less job growth in San Diego.   Also, there is a five year postdoc rule so if you have someone that has been with you for five years you have to decide between offering them a lifetime job that will take months to approve and require an external search, or letting them go.   This system pits employers against employees and sometimes does not benefit either.  I would bet that many employees would actually trade higher pay for less security and this would allow the university to better compete with industry.
